Take his class if you want your faith in humanity restored. He can make the hardest of concepts easier to grasp and works through everything step by step. He is always willing to help and you might want to make his office hours a part of your regular schedule, because he just might make you see something you never saw. BEST TEACHER EVER.

Great person, great teacher. He explains things extremely well and even does unnecessary proofs that he doesn't test you on so you have to take a mental break in class. His tests are easy if you know the material and he is generous grader. If you have a good TA (who grades the quizzes and homework) you should get an A. Great professor

The only way to pass 143X is going in knowing the material. Darko's lectures are completely useless. Only take a class from Darko if you plan to teach yourself everything. Our class only got though 1/2 the curriculum in the whole term compared to regular classes.

Avoid his theoretical class unless you're really interested in calculus theory. You will fall behind the normal calc 3 and 4 classes. He's not a bad teacher, there's just not enough time for him to teach the content he wants to teach. He's a generous grader though.

This class did not fulfill my expectations based on the course description. His lectures have been slow, so that our class is well behind the "easier" ones. Terrible test grades somehow scale to good letter grades, so clearly   many students aren't mastering the material.
I don't really like his teaching style. Also, final and midterm were extremely hard!
Dull, dull lectures, consisting of endless proofs. Little/no practical applications were covered. Doubtlessly good for math majors, but useless if you want to learn how to use Linear Algebra.

Avoid this guy completely.Even though he is very skilled in Topology and Lebesgue Measure he can't teach.He is NOT helpful and his grading is beyond strict.Typical homework grade is 3.5/10.You will even get a zero.He makes you present homework problems and critics you infront of class.Do yourself a favor steer clear of this guy if you love your GPA
Darko is truly a modern day hero. His examples and love of the arctangent function make life worth living.
Darko is a god among men. (He also looks a lot like Gilligan.) Heee ees my favoreet professor of all timee. I wish I could have his bebes. He taught me to love polar coordinates. Word. Palabrizzle.
Very clear about his teaching and his midterms and finals are a cinch!
Best calc 3 professor this year.

Darko was a great professor, very helpful. Never put things on the exam that weren't gone over in class and always held a help session before where the study guide was the exam only with different numbers. Easy class to pass, all you need to do is go.
His class is really sleepy. I don't like his English. I guess he has a Russian accent. But the truth is, his exam scale is ridiculus. It's soooo easy to pass it.
Avoid at all costs.  Skip lectures and teach yourself from the book if you find yourself trapped in one of these classes.
Provides a good mix of proofs and examples, and assigns a reasonable amount of homework. Although his voice is easy to fall asleep to, he's very competent and communicates well.
Keeps a very light mood in the class and only has like five quizes a midterm and a final. The midterm and the final are ridiculously scaled so everyone passes...almost.
If you like a rigorous approach to math, here's your professor. Homework is not repetitive or boring. Attending review sessions is a must if you want to do well on the final.
A very rude and entitled man
I've heard it said that there are two types of philosophy professors at WPI: young, cool, open minded philosophy professors, or old men. Professor Gottlieb is in the latter category.

I think if you want to know why tenure is a bad thing take this class. This professor is so awful, he does not use canvas instead you submit everything through email not an attachment, THE BODY OF AN EMAIL for full 2,000 word essays. He makes all the women in class feel uncomfortable and said he "can't register the sound of women's voices".
I had him for PY 2712 and I really enjoyed him. As long as you participate in class and support your ideas you will get a good grade in this class.

his lectures are really long and doesn't really encourage conversation during the class. sometimes when you ask him a question he would say 'I guess you'll have to buy my book to find out". Yeah, you have to buy his book and write two good essays and do a class presentation. don't take this class with this professor.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Group projects--Tough grader

comment: Good class but your grade is mostly determined by two papers, which are tough because it's graded based on his opinion of your paper which is rough. I wish there had been more opportunity to prove that we knew what we were doing
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--Amazing lectures

comment: Good in class but I didn't feel like he graded fairly on papers, I was on track to get n A but he graded my final paper differently than he graded the other paper in the class.

You have two big papers and a few other small assignments after every class. He is extremely opinionated but overall a good guy and cares about what he says. If you do all your work it should be and easy A.

Gottlieb is one of the best professors I've had at WPI. He's engaging, has clear expectations and really makes you think. He is adamant about where he stands on certain topics, but it's not like he won't allow you to disagree. Just be able to explain yourself. He learns the names of everyone who is willing to speak up and is very friendly.

Presents an interesting set of ideas that tend to challenge the way most students think. Embracing these ideas is not necessary, but the he expects students to support any claims they make, and will rightfully do his best to pick apart these arguments. While he can be very critical in class, he grades fairly as long as you follow the instructions.

Some may claim he teaches only his own opinions, but what kind of phil. prof. would he be without passion? Great at what he does, very knowledgeable... Really makes you think about the world. If you want a mindless class, skip this one. But if you don't mind a little effort (minimal hw, 2 short papers), this class is honestly an interesting break!!

I thought he was pretty good.  We had to write two short papers and he doesn't assign grades.  I just got an A for writing them. He seems really smart and he's a nice guy. I'm taking him again for my inquiry seminar about the meaning of life. I like him more than other philosophy professors i've had. No textbook but we read one of his books.
He preaches his own views every class and ignores others viewpoints. Will shut down any attempt to refute his arguments and will be disrespectful towards those that show their opposing views.

I think he is a great professor and the reason im going to do my depth in philosophy, he is a really nice guy. He might seem tough at first but his classes are engaging. I really recommend him, he doesn't make you read to much and actually influences the way you think!

This class was a huge mistake, all he does is throw his positions at you and expects you to take them as your own and if you do not agree your grade terribly suffers, he has no helpful commentary what so ever, and  shows no respect at all. It is his way or no way. So i would much rather be stoned to death than have to sit through this class again.
Professor Gottlieb is incredibly well organized and very clear about his expectations. This class was unlike any other I have taken at WPI and I recommend it to anyone interested in the environment.

Professor Gottlieb was my second college philosophy teacher. I started a sufficiency project with him in 1981, which I have not yet completed.  Thirty years later, he still makes me think.  While we do not always agree, he has never disrespected my well thought out beliefs.  Disagree, but defend your point of view well and you will earn his respect

Pushes his own point of view on students. Other opinions are automatically wrong if they do not agree with his. This professor needs to learn to be a professor more than a preacher. Students are supposed to have their own thoughts. It's a philosophy class, after all.
This guy is the man. Take his class.
the first book by hume is unbearably boring. the lecture is mostly gottlieb talking. he'll sort of attack you verbally if he strongly disagrees. don't forget to do the summaries and papers.
he preaches his beliefs to his students.  do not take his class.  it was awful
Horrifically condescending.
This guy sucks. Avoid him at all costs. He is HIGHLY BIASED towards his proud atheist jewish views. Very liberal feminist (even though he's a guy)

Keep an open mind and do the reading. If you can't comfortably do all of the reading, at least skim it, and write a summary (no summaries = no pass). He's a fun guy and has a good sense of humor. Recommended.
This guy is the man!

You will learn in his class.  While he can be somewhat harsh in his gradings, I noticed that it was only the students who massacred the English language and didn't do the readings who did poorly.  He provides humor and context to his explanations, and while he does give his own beliefs, he does not put down others'.
hard grading of papers, gives very boring book to read
Definitely pushes his own views and will not accept yours, but at least he grades fair anyway and is a really good teacher.

His ideas were different and I was skeptical but this guy is wicked smart and knows his stuff.  He does introduce you to a lot of his beliefs but doesnt force them on you just opens your mind.  Thoughtful assignments and he was a fab Suff advisor.
puts a lot of his own ideas in there, but encourages you to criticize them.  Very fair professor.
Interesting teacher.  Be prepared for meditation.  Interesting topics to learn about.
my favorite professor of all at wpi.  his classes are challenging yet insightful
Good guy.  I really liked his philosophy of the environment class.  I thought the meditation was gonna be stupid hippie crap, but I came out of that class feeling great every day.
Great professor
An absolute delight to work with and has immense knowledge. He gives good and precise feedback on writings. Of great help when you seek it!
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: great professor that cares about his students, defiantly one of my favorites at WPI.

Professor Cullon was my favorite professor throughout my time at WPI. Haven taken multiple classes with him, I saw how great of a professor he is in the classroom and how kind he was as a person even outside of the classroom. A good amount of reading and writing is required, but he gives feedback and is always willing to discuss and help students.

Professor Cullon is a very caring professor. He understands the workloads students have and is forgiving on deadlines. There is a lot of reading but skimming the reading and listening during the discussions usually give you enough information to complete the reading responses. No exams or final.

Had him B21 and his class was quite easy. Joe is a great guy who is always willing to lend a helping hand to a student in need. However I remember he tended to give out grades all between 85-91, making it easy to get a high B, but hard to get a low A. Occasionally worked in groups, and very little homework. Overall a pretty good class.

Group work was bad, information literacy assignment was alright, and essays were challenging. He provides good lectures with lots of useful information. He really goes above and beyond to provide excellent feedback on assignments, and he allows you to revise an essay with his feedback. Good teacher overall, definitely recommend him.
rating_tags: Group projects--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: He is a good professor. He does not assign many papers, and discussions make up a large part of the grade. He assigns a decent amount of reading, but most of the time you can get away with not doing all of it. He is very understanding and will make the class easier if students are too stressed. He will gladly extend due dates.

Probably my favorite professor at WPI. Genuinely a fantastic teacher. Prof. Cullon puts in a ton of time, and this class was simultaneously interesting, informative, and not overly difficult. He is very kind, gives great feedback, and is responsive to student criticism/suggestions. I highly recommend taking any class with him.

I had him for the history of science and technology in B term and I enjoyed the class. Hes a very nice guy who is very caring.

The class is very easy, with only like nine assignments, but the only major complaint I had is that on most of his assignments the grades were all between 85 and 90, so pretty much everybody got a B I think.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Caring--Graded by few things

comment: There are only writing assignments, which have small grade ranges. It is easy to get a B, but you have to work hard for an A. He allows you to rewrite everything to improve the grade and is very flexible on deadlines. He is very helpful in office hours and you will get better at writing. I would not advise taking this class with harder classes.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Cullon is a very good teacher, he is always accessible and will be there to help out his students. He is a good lecturer and the exams are very doable with minimal studying. There were two papers throughout the term and revisions could be completed to raise grades. The group work is annoying, but participation is easy.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Group projects

comment: I took two courses with professor Cullon, these were both level 1000 history courses. Put in a decent amount of effort and received grades that reflected my effort, one A and one B. A lot of reading but if he doesn't do quizzes you can get away with not reading. Really caring and understanding guy, lectures aren't boring. No Tests.
Great professor that also has an amazing sense of humor. He really cares about what he teaches and it shows.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Inspirational

comment: Super great guy who loves what he teaches. He gives relatively easy quizes and wants to inspire students into what he researches rather than drilling the material their heads.

Cullon is a very nice professor. He clearly enjoys what he teaches and is easy to follow in class. He's very understanding both in the classroom and one-on-one. Unfortunately, he sometimes mismanages time and reading can be a bit long at times. Make sure to skim everything, pay attention in class, and reread through the powerpoints too.

Prof is nice and means well, but class is poorly organized. Syllabus did not indicate A/B cutoff. Graded easily/harshly depending on his mood (told the class and me individually). Sometimes replies to emails in a timely manner... To do well, skim through the longgg reading, meet with prof during O.H., ask how to improve writing, use PowerP for quiz

He is a great professor who really cares about the material and it shows. His content is clear and easy to understand but there is a little reading required for the homework that is easy but sometimes time consuming. He is so funny so his lectures are interesting and easy to listen to.
He doesn't really care too much for the specifics of an assignment. Heavy on reading and writing. Kind of scatterbrained.

He is the stereotypical college professor. And I mean that in the best way. If you think college professor this is who you should imagine. I highly recommend him for intro classes. He is really helpful and teaches what you need to know to be successful in college.

I loved taking professor Cullons class. There will be a lot of reading but skimming is usually fine. He cares so much about his students and their successes outside of his classroom as well! A super sweet and quirky guy. I definitely want to take another class with him.

Super funny guy. All lectures are discussion based and participation is a major part of your grade so make sure to add to the conversation. Reading every night for homework but if you skim it you'll be fine. Every major writing assignment he graded and let us rewrite if we wanted to for a higher grade. Put genuine effort in and you're guaranteed A
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Prof. Cullon is a nice guy, but his lectures are off topic and dull. Your grade depends on your participation as well as homework and essay responses. However, he does not hand out the rubric before he grades your material, so your first few grades will probably be low until you understand his style. The great thing is that there are no exams.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: One of best history professors at WPI. He always went over readings the next day so if you didn't get through the entire reading he would catch you up. Group work was meaningful and engaging, allowed me to solidify my knowledge on the environmental concepts at hand. Also a very personable guy, 10/10 would recommend
Never really ever got through everything during class, but lectures were engaging and interesting. He gives you exam questions to review before the test, so definitely do the review. Lots of reading.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: Prof. Cullon has a gift for synthesizing even the most difficult history material articulating what's important. He is always prepared for class, even if it is lecture heavy, and he is kind and understanding to all of his students. He is also a fair grader and gives helpful feedback. Get ready for a lot of assigned reading!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Get ready to read

comment: He's a very engaging and interesting professor. His style of teaching made me interested in the subject matter. The exams are not very difficult and his office hours really help you hone into the important details in order to study or write an exam in his class. Though the readings are long, it's very interesting. Definitely take his classes.

Two hours for twice a week you will be bored out of your mind listening to him talk about history, while incorporating students maybe twice the whole time. He just talks and talks and it is painfully boring to sit through. Also requires a ton of boring reading for each class.

It's a history class so expect a lot of reading and writing as per usual. There are about five "short response" assignments, two papers, and three tests. Professor Cullon is a great guy with a good sense of humor and is very understanding with due dates. If you show an interest in the class, and ask nicely, you can often get extensions if needed.

Both of his classes, I learned a lot interesting facts about history, which did not know prior to the class. A lot of reading materials, which he posts on mywpi and tests/quizzes were easy as well. I recommend him for a history professor and I plan take my inquiry seminar with him

He's very enthusiastic about the subject matter of Environmental History, and it shows in his lectures and teaching style. Very friendly person. He knew every student's name within the first four class days, and there were about 70 people in the class. A great deal of reading is assigned. Quizzes are easy if you review the power points online.

very good teacher. alot of reading assigned, 6 short assignments based on the reading and gives 6 choices for esasys but you only need to write 2, based on course content. midterm and final both open notes
very boring, tedious busy work, but do the work and you will get an A

Lambert was a solid lecturer and his explanations of things made sense, but the exams were designed to be almost impossible to do well on, and there were 4 of them. But, I will say the labs made up for it and they were designed well with the class content in mind. The lecture and lab went really well together in general.

He's a really great guy that can teach very well. Some lectures have a lot of unimportant information though, you learn to tell what's important. It was just fun to be in his class, he tells all kinds of fun stories and a lot of jokes throughout. I never felt lost in the amount of content, they were difficult but very fair, overall great classes.

Have to be honest here. Hes one of the kindest and most comical professors I have ever had. He also gets really into his lectures. However, his exams are very difficult and you really have to work hard for your grades. However, the upside to this class is that there are NO LAB REPORTS. Just whatever grades your TA gives in your notebook matters.
rating_tags: Test heavy--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: He is a funny and nice Professor. He has a lot of office hours and you can always ask him for help. The class is very difficult. It's probably the hardest class I've ever taken in my Freshman year. The exams are rough and the class is based on 75% of exam grade and 25% of lab grade.

Professor Lambert is a super chill guy. He taught this class a lot better than CH1040 and I actually learned a lot about thermodynamics. The only issue I have is you are only graded by 4 exams. He does let you drop one tho so there is a plus side to that.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: Lambert is a funny and chill guy, and you can tell he's passionate about the subject, but the way he grades is anxiety inducing. His exams are either the easiest questions (see: what's the atomic mass of oxygen?) or the hardest questions you've ever seen and probably won't even be able to decipher. Overall he's okay, just a rough class.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things

comment: I'm not one to complain, but if you take this class, be ready to work for it. Make sure Microsoft Word works too, because if it doesn't he'll take 10 points off your midterm/final, which would most likely already be in the 60s. If you don't get an A or a high B in this class, you will fail, as you need two exams above 60 but the class if lab heavy
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: He expected a pretty good level of orgo knowledge, but gave a quick review when he realized we didn't know much. Exams are pretty difficult, but he balances it out pretty well with the lab grades. I would say it is a content heavy course, but I enjoy it and would take it again!

Horrible teacher. Lectures are barely understandable. He says that you don't need orgo knowledge to take the class, but 90% of the class is orgo. First test average was a 58%, a week after grading, no curve. The only good thing I can say is that he is almost always available for help.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Topics covered in this class were no joke but the grading scale is easier than a lot of other courses. A lot of this class covers some organic chem which is surprising since this class is taken before orgo.

His lectures are average, hes a tough grader and exams are hard. Where he really shines is if you visit during office hours. He will sit with you for hours explaining anything you don't understand and his office hours are most of the day so you are sure to have time to see him if you need to.

Great teacher, nice guy. He had loads of office hours for this course and I spent sometimes an hour at a time talking things over with him. He was delighted to help and he always ended the meetings with "feel free to come back if you have any more questions".

Very funny and goofy English guy. He's a Liverpool fan so where your epl jerseys if you have one. Lectures are good at explaining concepts and what you need to know. The concepts aren't simple but you'll get it with practice. He posts worksheets with practice problems. He made lab actually mirror lecture and even cancelled lab a few times.

This class is very difficult. Get ready to struggle through the concepts and be failing midway through the class. If you are failing through he will contact you and help you through it. He is hilarious and a very nice man.

If you get him you have to go to office hours.  His lectures are interesting but they spend more time on conceptual/background stuff and less on how to actually do problems.  But again if you go to him he will walk you through the problems.  His tests are all multiple choice so no partial credit was rough especially on long free response questions.

Lambert is a great lecturer and spends time giving good explanations on tough concepts. However, his tests are very difficult and not a great representation of his lectures. This is made up for with a significant curve. If you're looking to learn the material well, he's perfect. If you're looking for an easy A with little effort, look elsewhere.

Professor Lambert was my MQP advisor and without a doubt is absolutely brilliant, but he does not sugar-coat anything. He speaks his mind and is brutally honest, however these traits are invaluable. His rigorous methods helped me achieve complete mastery on my MQP for which I won an award. If your goal is to be a scientist, hes the best in the dept

Dr. Lambert is a difficult yet very intelligent professor.   He is always willing to help, but has exceedingly high standards.   He will respect you if you pay him the respect of attending class and putting in a solid effort.  He is very knowledgeable and highly recommended.

cannot believe this is a professor from wpi. he does not prove to be up to standard. class was a disaster. spent half the class talking about nonsense. grading criteria was not known. he didn't even have a syllabus for the class. tests were all over the place. do not take chem 4 with this professor you will regret it.

Horrible professor. Such a terrible experience with this course. Tried to receive assistance and guidance in this class but professor would not help. Never responds to my emails. I even called multiple times, but no call back. Lectures are disorganized and tests never cover material. Organic chemistry is a necessary to succeed.

No official office hours and his office is in gateway(far). Does not answer emails he might mention it in class but answers are iffy. Tests are all over the place and not structured by topic and sometimes topics wont't show up on test at all. Other times topics never mentioned do show up on tests.

He constantly contradicts himself and puts the same slideshows up every day, making everything as convoluted as possible. Every test has organic chemistry questions on it and all of these compound names that were never taught, since THIS CLASS IS TAKEN BEFORE ORGANIC CHEMISTRY.

He does not have a syllabus. He spends class time going over the same slides for weeks on end, and this material isn't even what is on the tests (mostly general chemistry knowledge and some of the new material). No equations sheets, no periodic tables, no given information. You have to memorize EVERYTHING. Would not recommend.
homework assignments every week, 3 tests and 2 part final. material is hard but he is a very good teacher and willing to help students who need it. nice accent and funny makes class enjoyable

He's a pleasant guy. Is willing to help. His lectures are very helpful to master the material. Tests are easier than his hw. Hw is reasonable. Toughest part is the final. He makes you earn every point on the exam so do well early in the term.
Great teacher, provides fantastic explanations. Tests are difficult. Final was completely unfair to non-chem majors, and covered things that were never mentioned in class (pH, for example).
good teacher, sexcellant british/scotish accent, gives good explanations, not too unreasonable.
I really liked this prof.  He had a great british accent, sense of humor, and kinda reminded me of Mr. Bean.  lots of material covered and a kinda hard class, but i learned a lot
For the most part, all material was taught by reading off of powerpoint slides, which was very difficult to follow, especially when complicated equations/calculus became involved
Great and FUN class!!!
Awful class. After 2 tests, 80% of the class was failing.  Tests do not relate to anything done in class, at all, whatsoever.

Uses relevant examples in class, very helpful when it comes to questions. Can be hard to follow sometimes, but is willing to help outside of class. He has a good sense of humor, too, which really makes the subject interesting =)
Very knowledgable and helpful, overall really nice guy

Professor Savilonis is a great professor who simplifies the material so that it is easy to understand. 7 quizzes that are straight forward and easier than the homework. The homework is easy and unlimited attempts/time. His handwriting is sometimes bad, but if you look over the notes before or after lecture, it is  clearer. Take this professor!
He was a very good professor and especially was helpful during weekly quizzes. If you do the work and the assignments you should do well on quizzes.

The class had weekly quizzes that were tough with the amount of time provided, but class averages were generally okay. The homework was very easy and was always graded like a completion grade. There were no exams which was helpful. The lectures could be confusing and unclear, so I'd go to office hours for help.

While not the most helpful lecturer, he's always available in office hours and is much more helpful there. he gave a quiz a week and a homework a week, which were reasonable assessments of the material. I liked this class

Not the best at explaining concepts and giving practice problems in lecture. Learn mostly through homework (which is time consuming but educational). Useful & convenient office hours made the difference between a B and an A. Regular quizzes are good measures of material & partial credit is generous.
He doesn't upload notes and could be a little unorganized sometimes. But he's extremely helpful and nice. Actually cares about his students!

I absolutely love Savilonis' way of teaching. He's all about being realistic. He starts out the class with a simplified 1st law, and adds more and more detail as the class progresses, an excellent way to learn thermo. Cheat sheets are allowed on the weekly quizzes, which helps. Be prepared to learn new concepts, because the concepts are essential!
Best professor at WPI hands-down. Cares for his students and the class was one of the easiest. Lectures aren't mandatory and project was simple. Take ME 4429 with Savilonis

Savilonis is one of the best ME professors. you remember stuff because all quizzes have some reference to previous lessons. You can almost not study for the final because you've been forced to revise everything over many times, and painlessly so. Always helpful as well. Take him if you have the chance.
AWESOME GUY! Very helpful in office hours, tests are reasonable and grading is very fair. Great lecturer and can make the whole lecture room crack up

After taking RJP's class, you will find you are lucky to be in his class. He goes over homework problems in the class, so it is helpful to attend his lecture. His board writing needs to be more organized. His class examples need to be clearer. Sometimes I don't know what he is asking on the example. Overall, his class is not overwhelming. Take it!
Not the most exciting professor but he is helpful and his class is straightforward with minimal homework. A solid thermo professor.

One of the better thermo profs on campus from what I've heard. He makes thermo very logical and you learn the basic essentials that you'll need to pass the class. HW is very good practice for exams, so do them. A little boring sometimes, but he makes the material and subject interesting and easy to understand as long as you pay attention.

Engy Thermo.  Pretty good; he definitely knows his stuff, but he's very disorganized. You can tell he's been an engineer way too long... he estimates and takes assumptions often, without telling the class what he's done sometimes.  Weekly exams, pretty fair/easy (open note).  The hard part about homework is understanding what the page even says.

This professor is very knowledgeable, patient and smart. I personally enjoyed his class. I like his manners and humbleness unlike some of the snotty professors. He welcomes questions and bend backward to help his students.

Knowledgeable professor albeit quite unorganized. Grade largely based examinations. Reasonable expectations especially since exams are open book/notes. Highly recommend students to attend lectures although not mandatory.
Good teacher.  Very knowledgeable.  A bit unorganized.

Good guy, but bad teacher. He tried to introduce new idea, but b/c he is so unorganized students ended up not learning anything. Biggest problems I have is he jumps from topic to topic without warning, and give very confusing homework. Didn't learn anything from him, wish someone else is teaching biofluid. p.s. I loved fluid

He tried to be helpful, but his class material is so unorganized that I have no idea what he was trying to teach. I tried, trust me. His homework is full with formula and equation he never mentioned in class.

He is rediculously unorganized and unprofessional in and out of class. It is impossible to learn from someone who is unsure of the subject matter himself. Avoid him at all costs, he is one of WPI's biggest wastes of tuition.

This guy is a good professor who really wants the students to understand.  One drawback is that he may be a little unorganized on the board and with his notes and stuff.  However, he communicates concepts and problem solving well.
very unclear, lectures are very scattered and lack organization. smart and easy going but bad at conveying his point.
Absolutely amazing class...he is very clear, both in lecture, and in office hours, lots of repetition, tests are a little challenging but his grading system is so easy.
Great teacher for this course.  Knows what he is talking about, grading is fair, material covered on quizzes and tests is fair.  I am still an ME major because of this man.
Is it me or does Prof Savilonis look like Gary Busey?
Very nice professor. Easy going, and helpful outside of class. His notes could be a little more organized, but in all he's good.
This man is sooo cool! He knows his stuff and doesn't give you more than you need. Do the work and prep well for the quizzes and exams and your set. And, he's a funny lecturer.
Awesome, just awesome. An actual engineering minded professor. Take thermo with him, its only easy because he can actually teach it. If you do the homework you will pass no problem.
Sketchy?  yeah.  Doesn't really seem like he knows how to get his points across.  Definatley an easy-going guy.  Class doesnt seem organized, but he's a smart guy.
Great class,he is very helpful, fair and leanient!
No Comments

Had him D22 and his class is pretty cool. We had some short answer assignments, a few essays, an oral report, and his final is writing two essays. He tends to give a lot of B's and B+'s on his assignments which makes it tough to get an A however. Nice guy who is passionate about history. Overall I would recommend.

-very boring lectures
-sometimes plays guitar
-very hard to get an a

Steven Bullock is passionate about American History and tries to make his lectures enjoyable for everyone. Attendance and textbook are mandatory. The course is lecture-heavy with a few papers and group discussions. If you stay on top of the work, the class is great! A bit of a tough grader, but if you put in the effort, you'll pass the class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Great guy. Decent professor. Lots of interactive conversation a.

He is a pretty nice guy and makes a point of making himself available for individual questions after class. However the class itself is by far the hardest class to get an A in I have taken at this school. With new reading assignments each night (4 a week) usually ranging from 50-80 pages I spend more time on this class than my others combined.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read--Tough grader

comment: Professor Bullock is a kind and caring individual. What I thought was lacking was the seemingly pointless homework assignments and incredibly boring lectures. I took the class thinking we'd discuss more of the Civil War but we spent ten minutes on it. It is difficult to get an A in his class, but if you are interested in the topic take it.

Class is really not worth taking. Did not even come close to getting through all the material. Lectures are incredibly boring and he just puts up pictures on the board, no actual information. The information he says in class is generally useless. The papers are not long but he grades them extremely tough and it is unclear what exactly he wants.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: While a nice enough guy, Professor Bullock makes it extremely difficult to get any grade above a B. That being said, I was able to write all of my papers early in the term and because of that did not have any homework for the second half of the term. He genuinely cares about his students, but be prepared to sit through extremely boring lectures.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: The essays assigned are almost impossible to get an A in. The essay prompts are also poorly written. His expectation on said essays is very different from just about everyone's previous writing styles (which he will deduct points for).
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Can't use computers during class, very hard grader on papers. Lectures teach you nothing so you'll learn the final material on your own
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Took my Inq Seminar and a few history classes with him. Also I see him on campus quite a bit. Real inviting, nice guy that loves his research. Class is usually a discussion of perspectives on history, as would be expected. Lots of reading. In general he's not too exciting, but if you like American history he's your guy.

He makes you work ridiculously hard for an A, and all of the comments he writes are 100% illegible. I went to his office hours and he could not even read the comments he wrote on my paper. He also gave me a B on a paper because he thought I used an incomplete sentence and then he realized I didn't but  didn't change my grade. He's a nice enough guy
rating_tags: Tough Grader--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: I took my inquiry seminar with Professor Bullock. If you want an A, there are better options out there but it's not impossible to get an A from him. He is a very nice guy but a harsh grader who expects a lot out of the revisions if you want an A. His lectures are borningist things on earth and he has a no screen policy so the class time is a grind.
Makes sure to share several good sources of, well, sources.  Loves the topic, very knowledgeable.  Plays guitar.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: There is not much homework, but there are a few short papers. You do need to put effort into papers in order to get high marks. I found his lectures to be fairly boring, but informative. He does send out a "what to know" list before the exam, which is very helpful. This class is not an easy A per say, but it would take work to fail.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Not many assignments and attendance in mandatory.  Also is a very hard grader. Sometimes he sings and class is entertaining but most times its just lectures. If your going to take the class know what your getting yourself into.

I did not enjoy his class at all. The lectures are extremely boring and vague. He doesn't give many assignments but when he does, he grades them toughly. So if you do take this class, I recommend putting lots of detail into your papers. Also the mid term and final are 50 min and difficult and out of 54 people, 2 got an A on the midterm. Good luck!
A great teacher with sometimes boring lectures. It can be a fun interesting class too.

Took my Inq. Seminar with Professor Bullock. This guy is super helpful and becasue of him I really enjoyed working on my seminar. His comments are really helpful, and I enjoyed this class more than most other history classes I took, despite not really having much interest in Washington and the Cherry Tree (at the beginning of the class).

Bullock is a really good guy. I like him a lot and he tries to keep the class as interesting as possible.  Although it can get boring at times (2 hrs), he is very entertaining and fair. He gives out a fair amount of homework and is a fair grader. He is pretty cool and he's sung to us in class and acted out scenes from history. Take his classes

Take a course with this guy. He's very fair with the amount of work he hands out (maybe five written assignments all term). He only gives a mid-term and final which are hard because their long. Overall an awsome teacher and I would definitely recommend him.

Good teacher all around, very fair with the amount of work assigned. Graded pretty fairly, though his handwriting is on par with a seismograph so don't expect criticism without asking in person. Tests were hard but fair, prepare for the essays because you don't have much time to write them!

Starts every class with an "Alllllllriiiight."  Funny and engaging guy.  Very considerate and helpful.  I passed a paper in a day late and there were no points taken off because I told him it was going to be late.  Show up to class though, he take attendance every class, besides, he might just play his guitar and sing slave spirituals for you!

Very interesting teacher, but can ramble on for all of class. He says, "Yeah....yeah...I see....Yes....I see...." a lot when you mention something to him. I only had to write four papers throughout the entire term with a mid and final, easy workload, interesting, an excellent teacher!
umm...ya...ya...actually, ya...yes...YA...Yes...YES.  A good guy, almost entertaining at times.  Not tough, reasonable reading assignments.  Make sure you go to class, he takes attendence.
Be prepared to read 100-200 pages per week. Discussions are the norm and he is a very critical grader. But he is hands down one of the best humanities professors at WPI.
I learned quite a bit in his course. If you take his course, aim for a B because that's what most will end up getting

He's a great guy. The workload isn't high and he does a great job of explaining things in lecture. He gives us plenty of oportunity to ask questions and offer opinions. There are only 2 (essay) tests and it's hard to get an A on them but easy to get a B.
Excited by subject, makes it interesting. Always willing to help, answer questions. Great exams!
Very nice guy, was helpful when I had a problem. Very excited by History.... but at least the lectures are entertaining
Kinda boring, but easy and VERY helpful and polite!
No Comments

Best professor ever. Always willing to help and will get to know you if you show up to class and show that you want to succeed. His lectures are thorough, although fast, and he will often end early. His exams are straightforward, and as long as you keep up with the homework, you should do well.

Professor Albano works with all of his students to make sure that they can withstand the work load and focus on their other courses. He does a fantastic job accommodating every student and his lectures and exams have been a gif help in learning the basics of Analytical Mechanics.

Truly one of my favorite professors at WPI. Class was hard, but lectures were very clear and super useful. He had regular office hours and was always happy to help you out. Lots of homework, but always useful & never "busy" work. He gave lots of partial credit, and would explain how you went wrong. Highly recommend both the class and the professor.

Prof Albano was always available for help in his office hours. Homework was daily and sometimes difficult, but was harder than the actual exams. Exams were about practice, not memorization, so I learned a ton. Only hw, four exams, and a project. He curved though. Amazing prof, take this class if you have to choose between statics and this.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Respected--Graded by few things

comment: This class made me switch out of engineering. However, the professor was extremely sweet and cared about his students. Homeworks were hard and daily, so I spent a few too many stressed out nights. Still, partial credit saved everyone. Final project was easy enough and in pairs. Lectures went a bit too fast if you took notes.
Best professor at WPI.

Professor Albano is incredible. He is clear and concise in his lectures, and is always willing to explain things further if you get confused. There is a lot of homework, but it really helps you understand the material. He is extremely helpful in office hours and is just a genuinely intelligent and kind person who is willing to put in effort.
Just read the reviews. Best professor at WPI by a long shot. Can't go wrong with him.
Great teacher, great guy
He is the most helpful professor I've ever had! his class is so clear that almost every one understand!
Albano is an amazing professor.  Everything he taught was perfectly clear and nothing ever got muddled.  If you need help, he's very helpful at office hours.  He is AMAZING

AWESOME TEACHER! So so sooo clear on the material. He uses the class time very well, and explains everything. Very flexible with office hours too! I'm sad he isnt teaching the rest of the CE2000 series
Not a practitioner.
THE BEST, Jerry!  THE BEST!
He is very helpful & cares about the students' understanding.
Lot of Homework, but easy to understand with Albano.
We have a saying...The father, the son, and the Lenny Albano. Thats how good this guy is.

The best teacher you will ever have. He is one of the nicest guys you will ever meet. He tries really hard to help you learn and understand. He gives a lot of homework, but I have learned so much from this course. Take his class!
One of the top 5 professors at WPI.
Albano is the best teacher you will ever have. He can make everything a lot more interesting than it already is.
Albano is the man.  Very good teacher.  He really knows what he's teaching and communicates it very well.

Len Albano is a great teacher. He is very knowledgeable and understands the material he is teaching.  Helpful in answering questions and writes constructive comments on work.  Take as many introductory civil classes with him as possible.
Very cool guy, doesn't bust your balls with stupid questions, you come out knowing what you're supposed to without undue stress.
Great with my classes and my MQP!!!
Great Teacher
LOTS of homework.  But gives lots of examples; he's a pretty funny dude too.  "I know at 9AM, the last thing you folks want to do is talk about stress and force"
best teacher i've ever had!
Great guy, and great teacher... Homework is hard but really helps you to learn!
No Comments
Captain Lou!!! Good teacher, great guy
One of the best teachers I've had
No Comments

Grimm is the best professor I have had here. He genuinely enjoys teaching chemistry, and makes lectures fun, and easy to understand. Lectures are really helpful when understanding the concepts, with really useful lecture slides that he posts ahead of time. He is very approachable, and his office hours gave me an opportunity to better grasp topics.
He's knowledgeable, energetic, helpful, and grades pretty liberally. He's also kind and easily accessible outside of class.

We had daily homework which consisted of 4 one point questions on Pearson. Our exams were split into two parts, a take home and an in-person, we were allowed to have an index card for the in-person portion which helped a lot. The textbook wasn't necessarily a requirement but helpful. Missing lecture = being confused. Grimm is great!

Hilarious guy and the lectures are clear and entertaining. He practically tells you exactly what problems are going to be on tests. Beware, exams are EXTREMELY cumulative but not egregiously hard. Also, he has pre-recorded lectures in case you miss a class or just want to be retaught the content. Overall good class, would recommend it.

He gives his lectures with great vigor and ...abnormal... sound effects (which I think was pretty awesome). He's also great at explaining stuff, really clear about what you are expected to know for the tests, and made chem much more interesting than I expected.

CH1010 is generally regarded as a tough subject because it is so abstract, but prof. Grimm explains it pretty well so it's really important to attend lectures. If you do miss something, there are recorded videos explaining everything covered in the course. All his expectations are very clear. 10/10 would recommend!
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: His lectures in class were incredibly confusing for me with little worked examples outside of the recitation period. I found myself doing a substantial amount of work outside of lecture to understand anything he was saying.

I really wish he doesn't say jokes that he is the only one who understands them! The content is organized in a good way in the shape of presentations. The HW shouldn't take more than an hour a week. The exams are hard and tricky.

Material is organized in a more comprehensive manner than the corresponding textbook. Reading the book is still very helpful, however. Grimm focuses much of the course on visualization, and keeps a nice balance between the real world and theorization. Lectures are posted, but GO TO CLASS. Tests are moderately difficult, but partial credit is given.

The worst part about this class was having to watch lecture videos for an hour every day before class. The professor was good and gave good examples, which made the class much more interesting. He's definitely passionate about what he is saying. Despite the lectures being far too much, they were clear and well-explained.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: Grimms always willing to help out students and encouraged questions. Hes also easily accessible and answered emails pretty quickly. Hes very passionate about chemistry, and really seems to enjoy teaching. During class he flipped out over a student who wasnt wearing their mask correctly, but thats understandable. I would too, honestly.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious

comment: Prof Grimm is likely the most passionate person about chemistry you will ever meet. He has a big personality and a loud voice so sometimes half of lecture is just him yelling about how valence bond theory is actually wrong. Super passionate about the subject and he explains things really clearly. He is very clear about his expectations for tests.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious

comment: Grimm was a really good teacher in my opinion. He had us watch video lectures before each lecture date, which was a lot of work outside of class, but it freed up lecture time for everyone to ask questions. He was responsive through email and willing to spend time to give help. I had him for lab too and was an easier grader than expected.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: He is a very funny guy and has entertaining lectures that make you pay attention. The downside to that is he often goes off on tangents and can waste a lot of class time. He also once broke a projector remote by slamming it on the table because he was mad. Seems a little unstable but still a good teacher, tests are hard but dailys are easy.

Grimm is a very charismatic lecturer. I highly recommend attending all his lectures. He goes at a reasonable pace and his slides are illustrated and concise. He is great one-on-one outside of class (He does tend to take like 30 min to answer a 5 min question though). Search for past exams because his exams reflect them fairly accurately.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Great professor but going to his office hours is key. He really wants to help you, but you need to search him out. He records all lectures and posts them on canvas.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Prof. Grimm records his lectures, explains exactly what will be on the tests, provides extra credit on each exam, and has useful weekly recitations. The daily assignments are not very useful, but completing them adds a lot to your grade and they can be done within 20 minutes. I read the textbook but it was not necessary.

Grimm is just a man that loves chemistry that has a "idgaf" attitude. The lectures are recorded so it is very easy to just watch the lecture and get the same information you would of from sitting in the lecture hall. His daily homeworks sucked but they forced you to understand the material. He doesn't follow the book closely so its hard to follow
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: He is a great professor and is more than happy to help someone if they need it. His class was my favorite this term because he is a funny guy and the lecture was not boring at all.

He is a really great guy and talks about some very interesting things in lectures. He does tend to go off on tangents, so be prepared to read and study so that you don't fall behind. The daily homeworks are annoying, but are very easy to complete quickly. If you miss any, you can just email him and he will let you make them up no questions asked.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: He is very accessible outside of class. Care about his student and great office hour.

Sarcastic in a good way during lectures; daily 5-minute homework assignments are annoying and not particularly relevant, but weekly ask-any-questions-you-want sessions during class are extremely helpful. Would take again.

Prof Grimm is awesome. He's very approachable, and his office hours were absolutely key to doing well in his course. He never ridiculed anyone for asking "stupid" questions, and always made an effort to explain things in many different ways. Really cares about students
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: His lectures are very difficult, but they're that way so that you have a strong foundation for Chemistry in the future. Office hours are EVERYTHING and you should take advantage of them. No matter how stupid your question is, he'll always answer respectfully and never make you feel stupid. Read the textbook! Best professor I've had so far.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: As he says, attendance isn't mandatory in that passing the class isn't mandatory. Definitely go to his lectures. He gives you important information and makes it very clear what will be on the test. He also tells you what is on the test that he doesn't cover so you can prepare (and it's never difficult concepts). He cares about his students.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: A man with a passion for chemistry but zero regard (or ability) for teaching. Not to mention his lack of respect and regard for students
worst chemistry teacher ever
Really bad professor. He just makes everything complicated. He cannot simplify the material in class.

My favorite professor at WPI so far. He gave difficult homework,  and the required 2 minute daily assignments were annoying,  but he really carea about the subject and is very accessible for help, tests were challenging,  but of you go to the lectures, he basically tells you exactly what will be on them.  Would take again.

One of the worst professors I've ever had. Is completely self absorbed and gives lots of homework that usually has nothing to do with the tests. His tests never contain the material that he says will be on it and it makes studying for them almost impossible. Overall he is incredibly annoying in class and I would not recommend him to anyone.

Grimm was a great professor for P-Chem lab! Really enjoyed all the different experiments we did, and the organization of the class was cool (each lab group rotated between the different experiments each week, with two days to write the lab and one day to do the post-lab writing). He expects serious effort and enforces good lab techniques.

Great professor.  He's full of energy and made me like chemistry. His class took a good amount of effort, but I learned a lot and his teaching was straight forward. Very approachable and held "Chem Table" (office hours) in the dining hall after class instead of distant Gateway Park. I would highly recommend. Fair grader and gave clear objectives.

He's very interactive during class, there's few assignments, and he's an easy grader. The writing assignments get longer throughout the course, and the one issue I had with him is when he edited the prompt to a 6pg paper last minute during finals week.
Chill prof, lots of reading and writing
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--Clear grading criteria

comment: Samson is great--if you enjoy the material he teaches. He lectures for two hours, with a break or two throughout, and assigns lots of reading. He is clearly very knowledgeable of the content, and managed to teach me new things about some of my favorite buildings. Really enjoyed the trips to local buildings, as well as the final design project.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Get ready to read

comment: 3 assignments. Hardest of which is the midterm. If you ask him questions before or after class, you will be given a ton of help on your assignments. His lectures last the entire 2 hours, and his presentations are 90% images. The challenge is staying focused the entire 2 hours to absorb the info. Also field trips off campus!
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Gives good feedback--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: There are literally only 3 assignments in this entire class, his lectures are very dry and I want to sleep during them. If I wasn't going for a BS/MS I would NR it. The only things that were interesting were the tours of actual buildings, other than that you learn nothing despite having over 300 pages of notes every class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: He will lecture at you for two straight hours. Which, if you find the material interesting, will make for an exciting class. He does assign a ton of reading, which isn't mandatory but it does help with papers. Fairly easy grader, but your entire grade will be based on tests/papers (no homework/participation) so it balances out in the end.

His version of notes are slides with pictures of modern art on them, accompanied by little, or more often than not, no text. His lecture style is talking at you for two hours while making no effort to engage the class. The assignment prompts are convoluted, and it is very difficult to understand what he expects from you as a student.

His lectures often go over time, but that wasn't always a bad thing because it was always pertinent information. He definitely tries to keep the class engaged, but it was almost too easy to fall asleep in class. Only take this class if you have a passion for both art and history.

Extremely dry lectures. Lecture "notes" are simply slides of pictures without context. Sorry, but I wouldn't take it again; I don't find it engaging enough to bother with. Unless you're already interested in the subject before, don't expect this to be interesting.

Great lectures as long as you like the material. It would get really boring if you didn't.  He's a really easy grader. Never got less than an A after a few classes with him.  Don't even bother buying the textbooks. Never touched them and I've done well.

This man has a 300+ powerpoint slide presentation every day.. CLEARLY knows the material but its pointless information. The class itself is absolutely ridiculous I am halfway through the course and have not learned a single thing. If this class wasn't required, i would NR it on purpose because of how ridiculously stupid it is.
do well on papers and tests and you'll have no problem. Easy class overall. Boring lecturer but nice guy. Knows the material well. Show interest and like i said, write AWESOME papers.

Lectures did not excite for the most part, but he clearly knows a lot. A very hard professor to read. I thought I was doing terribly in his class until I wrote my final paper and took the final exam and got an A on both. The class is very easy to breeze through if you have prior knowledge.
Regularly goes over class time. Constantly asks, what should be, rhetorical questions in class and waits until somebody answers. Often incorrect about historical facts.

Assigns some of the most incomprehensible assignments, that have very little to do with the readings or lectures. Relies heavily on Powerpoint, but doesn't bother to label the images, so you don't know what you're looking at. Regularly goes 10-15 minutes over class time. And he just absolutely refuses to pronounce anything correctly in French.

Class can be kind of boring, but if you're new to the material, it can be interesting w/ a lot of new facts and stuff. He assigns occasional (about 3-4) short writing assignments, and is an okay grader. The tests are matching + an essay. He gives the class hints about what to study, etc. for the essay.
Class is so boring...I dropped it, he expects you to learn everyhting from a textbook with out any background information and drones on about slides in class.

Knows a lot of stuff. Shows slides, and will put up a list of slides on myWPI. Can be kind of boring at first, but if you pay attention, you'll learn a lot and he can be interesting. Makes awkward jokes sometimes randomly. Not much hw. But, a lot of reading, writing assignments. You can do well on term paper if you make good use of the texts.
VERY smart guy. Loves to wear square ties. If you can stay awake, you'll catch the witty jokes he throws in every once in a while.

This man is exceptionally intelligent in his knowledge of Art. Classes consist of many slides, can be boring, overall interesting. A lot of reading in general. Usually 2 tests and a Final Paper(8-10 pages). Fairly easier grader. Good option for humanities. Have to admire his preparation & devotion.

it would have been a much easier class to handle and im sure i would have learned and understood more if he didnt throw so much into the class.  The walk around tours are interesting and a good break.  He knows his stuff, but its tough to handle for a couple hours.

Classes can be a tad boring with all the slides but an easy grader if you have even the slightest idea of what you're doing.  Knows his stuff very well though.  Generally an interesting and fun class, just make sure you get enough sleep the night before.

Lectures a lot because he really really knows his stuff. Can be a little boring but he's a really easy grader. Also, funny (and sad) when he uses the words "Beef-cake" and "Cheese-cake" to describe artwork (Masculine and Femenine respe

His classes were the only classes at WPI that I actually enjoyed. Sometimes boring, but he's very smart. 3000-level Modernism & Mainstream seminar was great, although only like me and another kid actually talked in class, which made things frustrating

Did anyone else notice that he looks like an Angry Chipmunk?  During one exam, the projector wasn't working and he turned red, spit angry mutterances, and stomped out of the room and slammed the door behind him.  Boring class, easy grader.
Class is very very borring, makes you read a lot but doesn't really test you that much on the readings. Really really easy grader. Know his stuff well though.
Class is boring, makes you fall asleep in minutes.  You watch the same slides over and over and over again.
Class is usually pretty boring, but a very easy grader. Tells you exactly what's on the tests.
Amazing professor!!!
IN this class, all he showed were slides and it made me fall sleep everyday
he knows way too much about architecture history and makes you learn it all
Rip prof Dean O'Donnell, great prof, and hilarious person, you will be greatly missed.
Rest in Peace, Dean O'Donnell. You were an amazing teacher and a great person, who influenced so many people to join the field. If anyone here deserved a 1-Up, it was you.

He is more laid back than most Professors, but the breadth and depth of experience/wisdom he shares through his stories is incomparable. His classes focus on learning rather than grading  so if you're only in college for the piece of paper then steer clear, but otherwise his classes will be among the most fun and rewarding classes you take at WPI.

Awful. He'll probably read this in class too. Nice guy, but his insight and knowledge is lacking. Easy work and got an A, but was so frustrating due to his incompetence. Amateur hour at best.  Grades quickly and arrogantly without reading the assignment, most of his "critiques" were questions that would've been answered had he continued reading.

Granted, he can get VERY sidetracked and distracted, but it was a generally fun and easy course. I'm pretty creative myself, so the essays and projects were graded in a fair manner. Comments weren't that helpful, but didn't matter to me. I guess his lateness in getting the blackboard site up should be mentioned.

Dean will not reward hard work, he will take magnitudes of points off a paper with little reason given. He disrespects student, especially behind their backs. Will never give a complete lecture. Grades are not given for months. Didn't put course on blackboard until 3rd week, but expected us to read detailed assignment work on blackboard.

He knows his material and he's a funny guy. The classes are very open to discussion however as someone who really wants to learn as much as possible about game design, I felt that he took forever on certain things and would go off topic too much. Oh, by the way, it took him about 5 weeks or so to get our stuff graded. Why? Had to clean the roof.

I've taken several classes with Dean. He's a very good professor and his classes are interesting, which is more than I can say for most. I just finished my humanities seminar with him and it was amazing.

Take a class with this man and you will wonder why you are spending so much money to go to this school.  He is absolutely the laziest professor I have ever seen.  His grading is completely arbitrary, and inconsistent..be prepared to wait weeks at a time for feedback on your homework.  Do not attempt serious discussion in class, he will ridicule you
The laziest and most laizzes-faire teacher on this campus. Why don't you decide to do your job for once? Not only do you make WPI faculty look bad, but you also make WPI graduates look bad. Fool.

The bottom line, he is an entertaining guy with interesting viewpoints, but often does not teach the core material thoroughly.  He is more of a speaker than a teacher.  Very lenient in grading.  Fun class.  Took for Social Issues in IMGD, but I would recommend Philosophy and Ethics of IMGD for a greater understanding of core issues and ethics.
This man is not a professor. He curses and is an entertainer. His class is fun but he does not teach, nor does he know how to fairly grade.

He was a wonderful teacher, we had excellent discussions during class, everything was laid back, and I had a great time.  Sometimes we got sidetracked and did not go through all the material we had planned, however, it was an excellent class, I enjoyed it alot and would reccomend it to anyone.

Dean is the man - the most dependable, reliable individual you will ever meet. He often tries to take more than he can handle which results in late assignments, but he helping everyone at the same time. Highly recommended and awesome for project work.

Not a teacher I would recommend. Doesn't really know what he's doing. Likes to act like he does. Makes up grades for assignments. Penalizes students for handing in late work but is often unprepared to teach a class and gets graded assignments back to students very late. A bad, bad teacher.
Awesome, he rocks.  Very approachable, with great attitude!  Highly recommendable!!!!!!!  Take his Class!!!!!

Really enjoys the work in this field, and understands there is more than just game design needed. He is easily approachable, whether it's trouble in class or just to chat. He wants his classes to be fun above all, but there is still much to learn. Keep your eyes open.

Insulted me publicly in class for a difference of opinion.  Assignments make no sense and he refuses to clarify.  His class was frustrating enough to make me change majors.  Thankfully, now I won't have to take any of his classes again.
He's a good guy, I like his class, but his directions on assignments are vague and unclear, thus leaving students in a problematic situation.
Although he does get off topic easily, if you pay attention and do the readings you will learn a lot too--he's just more subtle in his approach than most profs.

We had a class in gaming and he made us play a game for class.  He has coarse language, but he makes you relize that professors are normal people too.  The class was experimental, so its easiness may change.  As for the chile pepper, my avatar would eye his avatar any day, so strong yet sensitve ;).
He makes class fun, as long as you can read and write its not hard.  Very relaxed and entertaining.  Encourages class discussions.
Good teacher, he gets off topic alot but that just adds to the relaxed atmosphere of the class

Great class, but def isn't boring n e more, you do have to do a bunch of projects which can be a pain in the ass, but its really easy and fun.  Dean's cool and failry easy to deal with, just do what he asks its not much

His decription of the class seems like a lot but other than a few short quizzes the class became more interactive with New Voices and your own project than actually being a class. Fun time and a good teacher!
Makes the class easy and there really isn't that much work...  He does sometimes get off topic, but I still looked forward to the class every day.

he doesn't teach very much, and his lectures don't reflect the reading very well.  there isn't much for analysis or critical thinking.  He gets off topic really easily and wastes most of class time on unrelated things.  Its not wroth your time.
He gives u a grade, you dont earn one.

Theater workshop was easy to the point of being somewhat a waste of time. The bulk of the course was working with New Voices and Dean did not teach during class, just chit-chatted. He's not bad, but don't expect to learn a lot.
Funny, easy. Three papers.  Even less work in theatre workshop. Good personality

Very boring lectures and his knowledge is way out-of-date, exemplified by his forgetfulness, pettiness with grading and overall poor demeanor. Simply reads from his slides. Office hours are just a kow-tow to this tenured drag on the faculty. Got a great grade but will never take a class with him ever again. You can do much better at WPI.
Term A - 2018 WPI had to correct the grades as "anomalies" were found. Students were unable to see 20% of the grade from participation.

There are four major homework assignments as of right now. One of them was heavily reliant on a server which he would insist worked when it didn't. It took days to convince him to consider the possibility that there was a problem. The material of this course is inherently challenging, but he is particularly unhelpful in answering questions.

This professor was great. Accessible outside of class, but the "help" wasn't always helpful as he is pretty forgetful. The homework is extensive and easily the hardest part of the course. Get ready to work. The weekly quizzes are open note and open book.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: His lectures are extremely long and kind of boring. Basically reads from the slides so nothing too special. Most of his slides are from Carnegie Mellon or extracted from the book. His pace is also incredibly fast.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--TEST HEAVY

comment: Great prof. Classes are difficult and time consuming, but they will end up being your favorite. Take comp architecture if you can.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Very knowledgable teacher and always willing to help. Usually covers the topics already in the textbook and is sometimes a little slow. Otherwise, he's a nice teacher to have. Also like how he curves the grades.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria

comment: Very clear explanations in lecture, grades very fairly and is open to appeals, and is very accessible outside of class. Unless you count having to compete with all the other people trying to get in on office hours, that is. Even still, for my class at least he has several TA's available for help as well.
Great Professor, but he lectures are mostly summarized parts of the book which you will read before he even goes over it. His quizzes are extremely hard too. Curves the grades based on class median
He can actually teach. Quizzes are a bit tricky but nothing to really worry about. Often overstays office hours to help people.

I would say he's a 'good' professor in the sense that he's knowledgeable in the area he teaches. However, I feel like instead of explaining the stuff he relies way too much on the textbook reading. Also his quizzes are just way too hard. I'm a straight A student and I was consistently getting 50's in my quizzes. Would not recommend.
Weekly tests which are open-book/open-laptop/open-notes. Homeworks were tough and required lot of time. Office hours are your friend, Labs are straightforward. Grade cutoffs are a bot vague.

No exams. Small quiz every week. Weekly programming assignment (2-5 hours, lots of extra credit). I thought this was the easiest class ever but I know others disagree. If you have any CS background you should get an A.

If you do not have any experience programming, this is a very difficult class in my opinion.  Homework assignments become very tough and class time does not always reflect what is needed for the homework assignments.  However, Professor Lauer and his TAs hold many office hours which tend to be helpful with the programming assignments.
Good lecturer; The homework assignments were challenging but great for learning and familiarizing yourself with the material.

Professor Lauer is a very good professor. Make sure to ask for help! Don't wait until the end to try to understand stuff. Make sure you read the book. Do the practice problems if you want good grades on the quizzes.

This course was a learning experience for everyone, including him. He was very helpful during office hours and through email. However, if you can not go to office hours, getting a good grade in the class is very difficult. Homework assignments were on things we had yet to learn and were very extensive.
useful class, not easy, professor was the definition of ok

Absolutely nice professor, teaches clearly and offers great help, and is willing to extend deadline based on students' requests. Projects and quizzes are somewhat tricky but doable. Definitely can learn much things from his classes. WPI is lucky to have him.
I've taken CS2303 and CS3013 with Lauer... absolutely fantastic professor, even though his quizzes are insane. His classes are the only morning classes I have ever looked forward to going to.

What more to say about Lauer? He's infamous in CS department, for his difficult (almost to midterm level) homework assignments and nit picky quizzes. I survived by having helpful friends and going to his office hours nearly 4 times a week. First time taking a class with him and definitely last.

Took Assembly. Super awesome and interesting class, though really difficult. The quizzes are impossible but really fun, and the homework are lab projects that are really interesting. The curriculum is lifted form a class at Carnagie Mellon, but he teaches it really well and it really gives you a new perspective on computers!

Not a good professor. Tells you that X exists, so go read about it and implement it in code. Prefers to brag about the 25 or so companies he's worked at over the passed 20 years. Honestly a terrible professor. His exams are unfair (full of trick questions), and his homeworks become exponentially more ridiculous by the end. AVOID LIKE THE PLAUGE

Absolutely useless as a teacher/lecturer. Gets confused in lecture and contradicts himself constantly. I made it through the class purely on the textbook, mostly because he was lazy enough to steal the entire curriculum from it. Quizzes are insanely hard - find a solution manual. I switched my entire schedule next year to avoid having him

Lauer is not one of your great lecturers. But his was perhaps the best course that I took at WPI. The projects were hard and each took over 20 hours. But I really feel I know something now. The course by saying "this course is not for hackers, but we make hackers". We laughed, but it was true! His TA had a thick accent but was awesome too.

He doesn't go over code and refers students to textbooks a lot but that's how you learn. He doesn't spoon feed you information but he points you to a direction. It's more time consuming but beneficial in the long run.
Professor is unhelpful and doesn't go over code in class. He just tells you to go read the book and learn about 'X' function.
We loved Prof. Lauer!  He really knew his stuff and was good at teaching it.  The class was hard, but it had what we needed.  The class was a real eye-opener, and never dull.

Not a very good Professor. If you have questions, he simply refers you to the textbook.  His assignments get progressively more ridiculous as time goes on, but he doesn't help at all. Got a problem? Go to the textbook. Honestly the worst professor I've had at WPI.

Worst. Professor. Ever. I came into this class with decent programming experiencing and left with less than I entered. Teaches through power points so he writes no code on computer. Tests are IMPOSSIBLE(typical average was 52). Programming assignments are easy fo rthe frist 4 then suddently become insanely hard. Stay away if you can.

I really loved her class though it was a lot of work. I learned more from her than I have in any other class so far. Doing the homework before class is essential. If you take the time to understand concepts you'll do fine. For the most part, the more you put into the class, the more you get out of it. Her style is not for everyone, however.

She's grading on a rubric, (read high stakes). If work isn't perfect it's wrong. NO PARTIAL CREDIT. You MUST watch the microlectures . You'll get a solid understanding of the material.
